Shrine of Oaths.description:
Shrine of Oaths is a D&D 5e adventure for levels 3-4, blending dark fantasy, mystery, and dungeon crawling. This 3-4 hour adventure is perfect for groups who enjoy haunting atmospheres and uncovering forgotten history.

Once a sacred ground, this forgotten shrine was sealed long ago, guarded by the spirits of those who swore to protect it—even in death.

A recent collapse in the ruins has exposed the shrine’s entrance, and the party is tasked with finding Sir Emil Corvian, a knight sent to investigate the shrine alongside his men. What they uncover within its halls may test their courage, honor, and fate itself.

Horrifying Visage.name: Horrifying Visage
Horrifying Visage.description:
Each non-undead creature within 60 ft. of the ghost that can see it must succeed on a DC 13 Wisdom saving throw or be frightened for 1 minute. If the save fails by 5 or more, the target also ages 1d4 x 10 years.

A frightened target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the frightened condition on itself on a success. If a target's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the target is immune to this ghost's Horrifying Visage for the next 24 hours. The aging effect can be reversed with a greater restoration spell, but only within 24 hours of it occurring.

GM Note: Before using this ability, ensure that only valid targets (i.e., those who have not already succeeded on the saving throw) are selected. This prevents reapplying the effect to creatures that are already immune.

Possession.name: Possession
Possession.description:
One humanoid that the ghost can see within 5 ft. of it must succeed on a DC 13 Charisma saving throw or be possessed by the ghost; the ghost then disappears, and the target is incapacitated and loses control of its body. The ghost now controls the body but doesn't deprive the target of awareness.

The ghost can't be targeted by any attack, spell, or other effect, except ones that turn undead, and it retains its alignment, Intelligence, Wisdom, Charisma, and immunity to being charmed and frightened. It otherwise uses the possessed target's statistics, but doesn't gain access to the target's knowledge, class features, or proficiencies.The possession lasts until the body drops to 0 hit points, the ghost ends it as a bonus action, or the ghost is turned or forced out by an effect like the dispel evil and good spell. When the possession ends, the ghost reappears in an unoccupied space within 5 ft. of the body. The target is immune to this ghost's Possession for 24 hours after succeeding on the saving throw or after the possession ends.

The combat difficulty of this encounter can vary and depends on factors such as the level of the player characters, their magic items, the size of the group, the environment, the number of enemies, and the Challenge Rating of each enemy.

The adventure is designed for a group of 4 player characters of levels 3-4 but can be adjusted for other levels.

ADVENTURE SUMMARY.name: ADVENTURE SUMMARY
ADVENTURE SUMMARY.text:
The Shrine’s History

Long ago, the Shrine of the Oathsworn Knights was a place of worship, a sacred ground where knights and warriors swore their oaths, pledging their lives to justice, protection, and service.

When war called them away, the knights sealed the shrine with powerful wards to keep it safe until they could return. They awakened their ancestors' spirits to guard it in their absence, watching over the sacred halls as eternal protectors.

But none of the knights survived the war. Their order was lost, and the shrine was left to time, forgotten as the years passed.

The Recent Discovery

For generations, the shrine remained hidden beneath overgrown ruins, untouched by the outside world. That changed when part of the structure collapsed, revealing a passage leading into the sealed crypt below.

Travelers passing nearby have reported hearing distant voices, though no one has dared to venture inside.

When the shrine’s reappearance was reported, the Order of the Argent Watch took interest. The organization is dedicated to preventing old, abandoned places of power from unleashing dangers beyond their walls.

Sir Emil Corvian, Knight Petros Valescu, and Squire Gregor Marov were sent to investigate the disturbance at the newly uncovered shrine. As knights of the Argent Watch, their duty is to ensure that whatever lingers there is contained or laid to rest.

The Party’s Mission

The party must find their way from the crypt to the shrine, where they will discover that the knights of the Argent Watch are dead, and that Sir Emil Corvian has been possessed by an ancient ghost that protects the shrine.

It is up to them whether they persuade, confront, or exorcize the ghost to free the knight from possession and cleanse the shrine.

ADVENTURE HOOKS.name: ADVENTURE HOOKS
ADVENTURE HOOKS.text:
1. The Missing Investigators

The Order of the Argent Watch has not heard from Sir Emil Corvian, Sir Petros Valescu, and Squire Gregor Marov since they were sent to investigate the shrine. The party is tasked with finding out what happened to them.

2. The Fading Trail

While traveling between towns, the party comes across a recently extinguished campfire at the edge of a dense, overgrown forest. Nearby, footprints in the dirt lead toward a barely visible ruin, its stone structure half-buried beneath tangled roots and creeping vegetation. The ruins appear ancient and long forgotten, yet the signs of recent activity suggest that someone was here not long ago.

THE CRYPT.name: THE CRYPT
THE CRYPT.text:
The Crypt

Description

The underground entrance to The Forgotten Shrine consists of a network of stone corridors and chambers, primarily serving as a burial site. A large stairway descends into a central room, where the walls are lined with coffins, some placed in small alcoves, suggesting this area was a crypt for fallen knights or honored dead.

GM Notes:

  • Here the GM can hand @UUID[Item.orrPrIEzwNfj80jy]{torches} to the players.

To the north, a narrow hallway leads to another burial alcove, while an eastern passage opens into a larger chamber containing additional sarcophagi. This chamber has doors on both the north and south sides, with two statues flanking the southern door, possibly depicting guardians of the shrine. The room is furnished with stone benches, urns, and remnants of ritual objects, hinting at past ceremonies held in reverence for the deceased.

Signs of a Recent Presence

  • Boot prints in the dust are clearly visible under any light source. A [[/check sur 15]] check reveals that they were left by three individuals wearing heavy boots.

  • Recently burned torches can be found with a [[/check inv 12]] or [[/check prc 12]] check.

  • The scent of charred wood is noticeable in enclosed spaces with a [[/check prc 14]] check.

Encounters & Challenges

The Test of Honor

A faint inscription blending into the stone above the northern door requires careful observation to notice. The door itself is a heavy stone slab, designed to slide open.

A character must succeed on a [[/check inv 14]] or [[/check prc 12]] check to notice the inscription.

A Detect Magic spell reveals a divination aura on the door, indicating that it responds to words rather than force.

Once revealed, the inscription displays the following question:

“A knight stands before an enemy who has surrendered. What is the honorable course of action?”

Solution: The players must verbally state a response that upholds the shrine’s tenets of honor, justice, and mercy (e.g., accepting surrender, delivering fair judgment, or offering redemption). If they do, the door unlocks, allowing passage.

Failure: If the players suggest an act of cruelty, vengeance, or dishonor (e.g., “Strike them down,” or “Torture them for information”) or attempts to force the door open [[/check ath 18]], six skeletons will rise.

“Runes start to ignite across the coffins lining the room. A chant, barely more than a whisper, fills the air. The dead rise from their slumber, to punish those unworthy to walk the halls of the shrine.”

GM Notes:

  • Casting Knock on the door will not open it.

  • Casting Dispel Magic requires a DC 15 check.

  • If the door is opened by solving the test, it will remain open for 10 minutes before closing again.

The Test of Devotion

Inscribed above the south door are the words:

"A knight sees a wounded traveler on the road while on an urgent mission. What is the path of devotion?"

Solution: The players must say a response that reflects duty to others. Responses that emphasize compassion, responsibility, or placing the well being of others above convenience will be accepted.

Failure: If the players suggest leaving the traveler behind, questioning their worthiness for aid, or prioritizing their mission over an act of kindness, the shrine rejects their answer. A response that treats devotion as conditional or selfish is considered unworthy.

Whatever the response, the door open, but any character who fails to answer correctly or tries to force the door open [[/check ath 18]] is marked with a curse. For the next 48 hours, the character suffers disadvantage on all Persuasion and Insight checks. If they attempt to take anything from the shrine, they hear whispers of disapproval and suffer [[/r 1d4 psychic]] damage per object taken.

The curse can be lifted by a Remove Curse spell or by performing an act of generosity, such as donating wealth, healing another in need, or aiding someone without expecting reward.

HALL OF OATHS.name: HALL OF OATHS
HALL OF OATHS.text:
Hall of Oaths

Description

When the party steps into the chamber, the door slams shut and becomes blocked. The Hall of Oaths is completely dark. If the party carries a light source, they reveal a large chamber that once served as the center of the shrine’s most sacred ceremonies. The space is defined by high ceilings, carved stone walls, and a raised platform positioned at the entrance side of the room.

At the center of the platform, a stone coffin rests atop a series of steps, suggesting the resting place of a figure of great importance. To the left and right of the steps, gravestones are arranged in rows.

To the north and south, two smaller alcoves contain additional coffins, possibly belonging to high-ranking members of the order.

At the far end of the hall, stone statues of figures frozen in agony stand in place. Between them, a robed statue is positioned atop a pedestal, emitting a soft golden glow. One hand is outstretched, positioned as if to receive an offering, while the other holds a stone tablet.

In the light cast by the statue, the corpse of a knight lies motionless on the floor. He appears to have died several days ago.

GM Notes:

  • This is knight Petros Valescu.

A human figure in chainmail stands near the central stone coffin. His orange cape flows over both shoulders and his eyes are unfocused, locked onto nothing visible.

GM Notes:

  • This is Sir Emil Corvian, possessed by the ghost of Knight-Commander Ilian Varnes.

To the left of the coffin, the lifeless body of a young knight rests on the stone floor. The blood beneath him has dried, indicating he has been dead for several days.

GM Notes:

  • This is Squire Gregor Marov.

Then, without warning, the man in the orange cape stirs. His posture shifts slightly. He lifts his sword, first pointing it toward the players, then toward the glowing statue at the far end of the hall. When he speaks, his voice is heavy with solemn weight, yet it does not fully sound like his own.

"Are you pure or devout enough to enter here? Step into the light and let your voices join in the oath. Let the Keeper judge," he commands solemnly.

"If greed is what drives you, then you will fall as they did. They were warned, and so are you. This sacred ground is no place for the unworthy."

Possible Questions & Responses

Who are you?
"Names are lost but duty remains, sworn beyond death. The shrine endures, and so shall I."

What happened here?
"Fate was tested. They were found unworthy."

What is the Keeper?
"The Keeper is judgment. The oath unbroken. The final test of divine fate."

Who does the Keeper serves?
"Only the vow. Only the shrine."

What must we do to pass?
"The unworthy seek. The worthy offer. Kneel, speak, and be judged."

What if we refuse?
"Then your path ends here and the shrine shall take its due."

Why was this shrine sealed?
"Those who were meant to serve have not returned, and none have proven worthy."

Are You Possessing This Knight?
"This vessel carries faith, but doubt lingers. A blade forged with impurities will break in the final test."

Encounters & Challenges

The Keeper’s Judgment

If the party inspects the fallen knight near the light, they find a@UUID[JournalEntry.2LKpe3IBQuLucT3l]{parchment}in his hand.

If the party approaches the statue, they find a text@UUID[JournalEntry.79kGY1hMdloavnVU]{inscribed}on the glowing stone tablet. The words are carved in an ancient but recognizable script.

The GM should have each player recite the@UUID[JournalEntry.79kGY1hMdloavnVU]{text}aloud as written on the glowing stone tablet. Based on their performance, the GM should then apply advantage or disadvantage to the required [[/skill religion persuasion 15]] check. If a player recites the oath with belief and seriousness, they roll with advantage. If a player is hesitant, doubtful, or insincere, they roll with disadvantage.

  • If all Succeed: If at least four players succeed, the shrine is purified, the wards of protection disappear, and the ghost of Knight-Commander Ilian Varnes will free Sir Emil Corvian.

    "The duty now passes to you. The shrine stands cleansed, and at last, I may rest."

  • If all Fail: The possessed knight and the skeletons turn hostile toward the players.

    "Like those before you, you were warned. Now, join them in silence."

  • If some players Succeed while others Fail: The Keeper’s light strengthens, and the glowing aura expands by 15ft throughout the chamber for every successful check. For each failure, two skeletons emerge from the tombstone areas. The possessed knight and the skeletons turn hostile toward those who failed.

    "Those who have spoken true may step forward. The rest… must face the fate they have chosen."

GM Notes:

  • The ghost and summoned skeletons are hostile toward the players who failed. They will fight those players until death. In this case, all players will most likely join the fight. If they kill Sir Emil Corvian, they must also fight the ghost of Knight-Commander Ilian Varnes.

  • If the players do not proceed to recite The Keeper’s Judgment and instead interact with any object except the two dead bodies, it is considered that all players have failed The Keeper’s Judgment, and the fight will immediately begin.

How to Free Sir Emil from Possession

Scenario 1: Calling the Ghost by Name

If the players remember Ilian Varnes’ name (@UUID[JournalEntry.loHH5VaRl3eAkkHl]{from the wall inscription in the Crypt}), they can speak it aloud to gain the ghost’s attention. The first time they do this, Sir Emil hesitates, as if something inside him reacts to hearing his true name.

Skill Check:

A [[/skill religion persuasion 15]] can force the spirit to acknowledge them.

On a Success:

  • Ilian’s presence falters, and his attention shifts toward the speaker.

  • His voice echoes through Sir Emil’s strained breath, as if torn between the living and the dead.

  • The ghost finally speaks directly:

    "Why do you call upon me?"

  • The players may now plead, argue, or challenge his claim over Sir Emil.

Scenario 2: Sacred Exorcism

A player can attempt to use Turn Undead, forcing the spirit to weaken its hold over Sir Emil.

On a Success:

  • Ilian’s spectral form emerges, and his voice, now filled with anger, echoes through the hall:

    "You dare to cast me out? You think your faith surpasses my duty?"

  • Sir Emil collapses, freed but severely weakened.

Additional Consequence:

If this happens before the Judgment, four skeletons will also rise from the tombstone areas.

INTRODUCTION.name: INTRODUCTION
INTRODUCTION.text:
Shrine of Oaths is a Dungeons & Dragons 5th Edition one-shot adventure designed for characters of levels 3-4. It is intended to be completed in 3-4 hours and takes place within a forgotten shrine.

This adventure blends horror themes with exploration and problem solving.

GHOST KNIGHT.name: GHOST KNIGHT
GHOST KNIGHT.text:
KNIGHT COMMANDER ILIAN VARNES

Armor Class: 11 (Natural Armor)

Hit Points: 44 (10d8)

Speed: Fly 40 ft.

Attributes:

  • Strength: 7 (-2)
  • Dexterity: 13 (+1)
  • Constitution: 10 (+0)
  • Intelligence: 10 (+0)
  • Wisdom: 12 (+1)
  • Charisma: 17 (+3)

Senses: Darkvision 60 ft.

Damage Immunities: Cold, Necrotic, Poison

Resistances: Bludgeoning, Piercing, Slashing

Condition Imunities: Charmed, Exhaustion, Frightened, Grappled, Paralized, Petrified, Poisoned, Prone, Restrained

Challenge: 4 (1100 XP)

Actions

  1. Withering Touch. Melee Weapon Attack:+5 to hit,, 5 ft., one target. Hit: 17 (4d6 + 3) necrotic damage.

  2. Possession. One humanoid that the ghost can see within 5 ft. of it must succeed on a DC 13 Charisma saving throw or be possessed by the ghost; the ghost then disappears, and the target is incapacitated and loses control of its body. The ghost now controls the body but doesn't deprive the target of awareness.

    The ghost can't be targeted by any attack, spell, or other effect, except ones that turn undead, and it retains its alignment, Intelligence, Wisdom, Charisma, and immunity to being charmed and frightened. It otherwise uses the possessed target's statistics, but doesn't gain access to the target's knowledge, class features, or proficiencies.The possession lasts until the body drops to 0 hit points, the ghost ends it as a bonus action, or the ghost is turned or forced out by an effect like the dispel evil and good spell. When the possession ends, the ghost reappears in an unoccupied space within 5 ft. of the body. The target is immune to this ghost's Possession for 24 hours after succeeding on the saving throw or after the possession ends.

Features

  1. Horrifying Visage. Each non-undead creature within 60 ft. of the ghost that can see it must succeed on a DC 13 Wisdom saving throw or be frightened for 1 minute. If the save fails by 5 or more, the target also ages 1d4 x 10 years.

    A frightened target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the frightened condition on itself on a success. If a target's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the target is immune to this ghost's Horrifying Visage for the next 24 hours. The aging effect can be reversed with a greater restoration spell, but only within 24 hours of it occurring.

  2. Incorporeal Movement. The Ghost Knight can move through other creatures and objects as if they were difficult terrain.

    It takes 5 (1d10) force damage if it ends its turn inside an object.

  3. Ethereal Sight. The Ghost Knight can see 60 ft. into the Ethereal Plane when it is on the Material Plane, and vice versa.

  4. Etherealness. The Ghost Knight enters the Ethereal Plane from the Material Plane, or vice versa. It is visible on the Material Plane while it is in the Border Ethereal, and vice versa, yet it can't affect or be affected by anything on the other plane.

POST-ENCOUNTER.name: POST-ENCOUNTER
POST-ENCOUNTER.text:
If the shrine is purified—either by the party successfully completing The Keeper’s Judgment or by performing the one-hour ritual from the @UUID[JournalEntry.jJ4dnug3cyDs0pRj]{Knight's Prayer Book}—a warhammer materializes in the outstretched hand of the robed statue at the far end of the Hall of Oaths. Additionally, all doors in the crypt unlock.

GM Notes:

  • If the provided @UUID[Macro.Z9bJ2ypuOChgtFT6]{macro} is used to update the light emission radius, the warhammer will automatically appear when the light range reaches 75 or more.

If the purification is not completed, the warhammer does not appear. However, the party may search the coffins within the hall, recovering items once buried with the fallen knights. The doors remain sealed, and the party must force them open with a [[/check ath 18]] check.

If Sir Emil survives, he may express guilt for not being strong enough to resist. Some possible lines he might say depending on the situation:

"I... I couldn't stop him. He used me, turned my hands against my own oaths."

"You carried out the duty I could not. You did what was right. For that, I am in your debt."

"The oaths sworn here were never meant to last forever. You have set them free."

"How long have I been lost? Did I... harm anyone?"

"Petros… Gregor… I should have protected you."

"They followed me into this place, and I led them to their deaths."

Consequences & Follow-Up

  • The Argent Watch may reward the party for their efforts.
  • The shrine may attract scholars, priests, or other seekers looking to uncover its past.

DESCRIPTION.name: DESCRIPTION
DESCRIPTION.text:
We were the last keepers of this sacred place, bound by honor and by the oaths sworn upon these stones. Our charge was clear: to protect the weak, to judge the unworthy, to stand vigilant, and to protect this sacred place.

But duty does not always wait within the halls of stone. War came to the land, and the Order was summoned beyond these walls. We could not refuse the call.

And so, we sealed the doors. We set the wards. We laid our final rites, binding what must remain hidden.

We left behind only silence and stone, trusting that no one would disturb this place.

Though we march beyond these walls, our vow does not end. If we do not return, know this. Our ancestors shall stand in our place. Their watch is eternal, their judgment unyielding.

If your heart is pure and your cause just, then step forward and be judged. But if greed guides your path, if your soul is untethered from virtue, turn back. There is nothing here for you but the echoes of oaths long kept.

By our duty and our vows, the Order of the Oathsworn Knights, last guardians of the shrine.

This encounter unfolds in a forgotten crypt, an unholy place where a stone bridge spans a swirling pool of lost souls. Whispers echo through the air, carrying the voices of the trapped and the damned. The Soulbound Knight, an undead warrior bound to eternal servitude, wields a spectral glaive known as The Harvester. He uses ethereal manipulation and tormented souls to protect the crypt and its dark secrets. Beyond the bridge rises a formidable mausoleum, its massive stone doors guarding the secrets within.

As a reward, the players can obtain The Harvester, the powerful weapon imbued with ethereal energy wielded by the Soulbound Knight.

A journal is included, containing all the details of the encounter, lore, and tactical information.

ADVENTURE HOOKS.name: ADVENTURE HOOKS
ADVENTURE HOOKS.text:
As the adventurers trek through the snowy wilderness, they hear crashing footsteps and ragged gasps. A man stumbles into view, soaked to the bone, his hands trembling as he clutches a broken oar.

“Help! It... it destroyed my boat! A monster, it’s searching for something! Please, stop it!”

The man, is a merchant who was ambushed by the creature while navigating the river. He narrowly escaped as the abomination destroyed his boat, muttering about “the relic” and “a memory stolen by the frost.”

MAPS.name: MAPS
MAPS.text:
Snowy River

When the adventurers approach the scene of the wreckage, they see the creature's large, malformed form moves with surprising speed as it rummages through the wreckage. However, it does not immediately notice the adventurers. A Stealth (DC 14) check allows them to observe its frantic searching. It seems to be looking for objects of valor, items it believes are worthy of the dragon egg, as though it is trying to appease the egg or something within it.

If the party’s presence is detected, the Giant Abomination immediately turns to face them.

What... what is this? More treasures... for the egg!

At 20 HP or fewer, the creature flees, retreating toward its cave.

Tactics & Hazzards

The water is considered difficult terrain. Any creature that falls into the river must succeed on a DC 12 Strength saving throw to avoid being swept 10ft downstream.

The abomination uses Frost Trail to create icy patches along the riverbank, forcing creatures into the water.

It begins combat with Frost Missile, targeting groups of enemies.

Abomination Cave

After following the Giant Abomination to its lair, the adventurers find themselves in this icy cavern. The cold is immediately noticeable, and their breath hangs in the air as mist. The darkness is interrupted by a faint glow emanating from deeper inside. The cold light reflects off the icy walls, casting ghostly shadows and faintly illuminating the path forward. Snow crunches beneath their feet as they step into the open central area. The source of the glow becomes clear as the adventurers proceed: the white dragon egg resting in an alcove, glowing faintly.

The Giant Abomination is hunched over a pile of broken wood and debris. Its grotesque form is illuminated faintly by the egg’s glow. He suddenly halts as it senses the adventurers’ approach. With an enraged, guttural cry, it lurches forward, saying:

“You’ve come to steal the treasure! I’ll rip it from your corpses!”

When the Abomination is reduced to half its HP, it retreats to the egg chamber and lets out a desperate, guttural howl:

“No! The treasure must not fall to you! The dragon commands it!”

Tactics & Hazzards

At the start of its turn, the Frost Explosion deals cold damage to all creatures within 10 feet of it.

The Abomination makes two melee attacks with its Shiverstrike, focusing on whoever seems to be carrying the heaviest gear or magical items, as it views these as valuable.

The snowy cavern floor counts as difficult terrain for anyone without cold adaptations.

If more than two party members group together, the Abomination targets them with a Frost Missile.

If cornered, the Abomination creates a 30-foot trail of ice to obstruct the party's movement, retreating toward the dragon egg to make a final stand.

The white dragon egg radiates a magical cold aura within 20ft. Any creature except the Giant Abomination within this radius has disadvantage on all attack rolls.

LORE.name: LORE
LORE.text:
It is said that a mage, fascinated by fire and convinced of its potential for ultimate power, embarked on a journey into the heart of an extinguished volcano. Within the depths of the volcano, he discovered a chamber where the boundaries between the material world and the elemental plane of fire were thin, allowing him to harness the purest form of fire magic. Over time, fascination turned to obsession for absolute power, and after extensive experiments with rare materials and ancient incantations, he created the Infernal Crown, awakening the volcano in the process.

Proclaiming himself the Flame Tyrant, he initiated a destructive conquest of the surrounding lands. Villages and towns fell before his advance, consumed by flames. Survivors, terrorized by the flames that devoured everything in their path, fled to neighboring kingdoms, spreading rumors that the volcanic eruption was not a natural occurrence, and that a creature they named "Pyro Head" was responsible for it.

Mysterious Fires. Mysterious fires have been erupting in towns and villages across the land, leaving destruction in their wake. The pattern of the fires leads the adventurers to suspect that someone is using fire magic on an unprecedented scale.

Burning Plague. A remote village is suffering from an unexplainable plague that causes the afflicted to spontaneously combust.

Fire Cult Threat. A cult devoted to fire worship has grown in power and influence, seeking to unleash an apocalypse of flames upon the world.

LORE.text: Two ogre brothers, Grom and Grak, stumbled upon a large rocky overhang in a canyon during a fierce storm. INTRO.name: INTRO
INTRO.text:
From a distance, the adventurers can hear the brothers' voices caught in a fierce debate. They realize the argument is over a weapon of some kind.

Grom (bashing his fist into his chest): "ME has rights on big club! ME is older and bigger! Is why pops gave it, like older pops gave it to him! YOU have the whip now, so stop whining!"

Grak (snarling back): "Whip ain't good like big club! Big club crushes, big club breaks bones! Whip just stings!

Grom (smirking): "Whip good for scaring humans though. They scream loud when whip cracks. Maybe you not use it right."

Grak (irritated): "Me knows how to use whip! Me just wants real weapon, like big club. Me want to feel bones break, not just hear cries."

Grom (leans back, gesturing annoyed): "You don’t even know name of club, you too stupid, little ogre! Clan rule say oldest one gets big bad club and ME is oldest! ME will be leader and leader say big club is mine! Clan is strong with me! You dare challenge and I smack you silly like momma did when yous was small grub!"

Grak (stands back, grumbling with a sly grin): "Me grows stronger and yous grows older, brother. Me takes big club... Not today, but maybe day after. And THEN I smack you silly with big bad hard head on stick."

Rumors are spreading through the trading village, where fear has taken root. People are barring their doors and traveling only in groups, for those who venture out alone never return. Knowing that the ritual will transform him into an adult dragon, he tolerates the cult’s presence. A group of adventurers are hired to investigate the disappearances. Can they traverse the treacherous terrain, rescue the captives, and stop the cult before Volcathar's power becomes unstoppable?

HAZARDS.name: HAZARDS
HAZARDS.text:
Magma Rock (Optional Rules)

Recently Cooled Lava (Still Hot):

  • Magma rock that's only recently cooled but still extremely hot can deal 1d10 fire damage per round to creatures walking on it due to the residual heat. This could be described as a smoldering, cracked surface with glowing embers between the cracks.

  • If you want to add some danger to it, creatures walking on it could make a DC 13 Dexterity saving throw to avoid stepping on particularly unstable or extra-hot spots. On a failed save, they take an additional 2d10 fire damage as they step on a superheated spot that cracks open or releases steam.

Stable Magma Rock (Cooled, but not Dangerous):

  • If the magma rock has fully cooled and solidified, it’s safe to walk on without any fire damage. However, depending on the terrain, the rock might be rough, jagged, or uneven, potentially requiring a DC 10 Dexterity (Acrobatics) or Strength (Athletics) check to avoid falling or slipping, especially if running or during combat.

Lava (Optional Rules)

Touching Lava (brief contact):

  • If a creature touches lava briefly (e.g., a hand or foot grazes it), they take 10d10 fire damage. This would represent a quick contact or splash of lava.

Falling into Lava (submerged):

  • If a creature falls into lava or is otherwise fully submerged, they take 18d10 fire damage per round they remain in the lava. This represents the intense heat and destructive power of molten rock.

Standing Near Lava:

  • The heat from nearby lava can also cause damage to those who get too close. Creatures standing within 5 feet of lava should take 1d10 fire damage at the start of their turn due to the extreme heat.

BACKGROUND.name: BACKGROUND
BACKGROUND.text:
Rumors are spreading through the trading village, where fear has taken root. People are barring their doors and traveling only in groups, for those who venture out alone never return. Whispers of shadows in the night and an unnamed terror have seized the hearts of the villagers. Friends, family, and even passing travelers have mysteriously vanished without a trace, leaving the community gripped by dread as the disappearances continue.

A fanatical cult, hidden in the nearby mountains, is to blame for the disappearances. Led by Father Korvan, the cult worships a young red dragon named Volcathar the Flameborn. They believe that through worship and sacrificial offerings, they can bind the dragon to their will. Unknown to them, Volcathar only pretends to be controlled, fully aware of the cultists intentions. Knowing that the ritual will transform him into an adult dragon, he tolerates the cult’s presence.

The Vow of the Burning Flesh

The cult’s strictest commandment is the Vow of the Burning Flesh, an oath that forbids the use of weapons. Every initiate, with the help of their fellow cultists, must capture and offer a victim as part of their initiation. The cultists believe that true power comes from within and that weapons are for the weak, for only those who rely on their own strength are deemed worthy of channeling Volcathar’s flames. They aim to reflect the might of the dragon, who needs no mortal weapons to instill terror. At the heart of their combat style and ritual practice are the Bracers of Ignition, magical items crafted from Volcathar's scales. These bracers are gifted to each cultist after they take the Vow of the Burning Flesh. They see the flames that erupt from their bracers as a sign that the dragon’s magic flows through them.

SYNOPSIS.name: SYNOPSIS
SYNOPSIS.text:
Wasteland Encounter

Traveling toward the mountain, they come across a group of cultists herding prisoners to their hideout. After a confrontation, whether through combat, persuasion, intimidation, the adventurers manage to extract crucial information from the cultists. They learn of two key locations: the lair where the cult operates, and a site known as the Toothmaw Cliffs, where an ancient ritual is currently being performed.

At this point, the party faces two choices. They can either head to the cult’s lair to uncover its secrets and potentially rescue more prisoners, or they can rush to the Toothmaw Cliffs to interrupt the ancient ritual before it’s completed.

Ritual Site

If the party decides to journey to the Toothmaw Cliffs, they will face one of two major scenarios.

  1. Scenario 1:

    If they successfully disrupt the ceremony, the dragon will remain in his younger form. Weakened by the interrupted ritual, Volcathar will fight briefly, engaging the party for a round or two before retreating to his lair. Enraged and humiliated, he commands his cultists and Father Korvan to kill the intruders. Korvan, still deluded into thinking he can control the dragon, may also flee to the lair in desperation.

    Arriving at the lair, the party will find Volcathar in a foul mood, devouring the last prisoner while Korvan grovels for mercy. When the dragon sees the party intruding into his domain, his anger flares, and he orders Korvan to deal with the intruders. With his plans shattered and his pride wounded, this is the party’s best chance to defeat the dragon. If they can creatively taunt or lure him into fighting in the open, they stand a chance of slaying the young red dragon.

  2. Scenario 2:

    If the party does not disrupt the ritual, Volcathar successfully transforms into an adult dragon. However, weakened by the rapid transformation, he retreats to his lair, leaving the cultists to engage the adventurers. Korvan will also attempt to flee to the lair.

    • Outcome 1:

      If the cult leader manages to escape, the party can follow him there.

      Reaching the lair, the party will overhear a brief exchange between Korvan and the dragon. Still deluded, Korvan believes he can control Volcathar, but the dragon, amused by the cult leader’s arrogance, mocks him before incinerating him in a flash of fire. If the party chooses to engage the dragon and wounds him too severely, he will submerge into the lava, swearing revenge once he fully recovers.

      Volcathar will require 1d6 + 6 months of sleep to fully complete his transformation. Should the party touch his hoard, the dragon’s wrath will trigger a magical collapse of the cavern, and they will only have a few minutes to escape before being buried alive.

    • Outcome 2:

      If Korvan does not manage to escape.

      Reaching the lair, the dragon will remain hidden until they discover his hoard. Once they do, Volcathar will either engage them in battle or attempt to bargain. If he chooses to fight, his abilities remain the same as before, though his size has increased due to the ritual. Despite this, he still requires 1d6 + 6 months of sleep to fully complete his transformation.

      If the battle turns against him and he is critically wounded, Volcathar will retreat into the lava, swearing to hunt the party until the end of time. Should the players attempt to steal from his hoard, the cavern will violently tremble, causing the lava to rise. They will have only a few minutes to escape before the lair collapses.

Dragon Lair

If the party goes straight to the lair.

When the party enters the lair, they find it mostly empty, with only one prisoner held captive. As they explore further, they discover murals in the Great Hallway that illustrate the dragon’s plan to reach adulthood through a sacrificial ritual. At this point, the dragon will arrive in the lair from the ritual site in its adult form, though still weakened by the ritual. It will retain the same abilities and stats as its younger form. Wasteland Encounter

Intro

In the dark volcanic wasteland, the party encounters 4 cultists escorting 2 prisoners. The cultists, fanatical and aggressive, immediately attack, shouting:

Cultist: “You’ll be fuel for the ritual!”

Cultist: “Burn in the name of the Flameborn!”

If any cultist is still alive

The party can use Persuade DC 14 to extract information. The surviving cultist responds cryptically, his gaze fixed on a distant glowing red light. He says:

Cultist: “Look, the fangs of the world are awakening. His true power is nearly here! Father Korvan will bind the god to his will, and we will be reborn as fire lords!”

Cultist (pointing in another direction): “The lair where the god will be resting.”

Cultist (gasps with his last breath): “More lost in chains, both in the god's lair and where the flames claim their prize.”

If no cultists are alive

The party can Investigate DC 12 by searching their bodies. They find cryptic drawings and notes:

  • Drawing: Shows jagged cliffs beneath a red sky, with the caption: "Where the flames rise, so does he."

  • Note: Refers to the lair: "Return to the nest before the god is truly born. The lost in chains must be ready for the final sacrifice."

The prisoners might mention overhearing conversations among the cultists about "awakening the flame that will devour the skies." The party might notice a strange red glow pulsing on the distant horizon.

  2. Cultists

Toothmaw Cliffs

Intro

In the center of the map is a red fire vortex, spinning with intense heat. Anyone within 25ft of the center of the vortex must make a Constitution DC 14 saving throw or take [[/roll 2d6]] fire damage at the start of their turn. Surrounding the vortex are sharp, rocky spires that rise up to 20ft in height, resembling the fangs of some enormous creature. Players can climb or descend these spires, but if they want to jump, they need to succeed on a DC 12 Acrobatics check.

The party arrives just in time to witness a dark ritual in progress. Father Korvan and five cultists are preparing to throw prisoners into the vortex to fuel the ritual. Five other cultists stand guard. The young red dragon Volcathar circles in the center of the vortex, surrounded by flames, waiting for his transformation into an adult dragon to be completed.

Tactical Information

Every round, a cultist throws a prisoner into the vortex.The GM may choose to have Volcathar unleash his fire breath at this moment.

If 3 prisoners are sacrificed, the ritual will be complete, and Volcathar will transform into an adult dragon.

Once transformed, the adult dragon will fight for 1-2 rounds but weakened by the transformation, he retreats to his lair.

The party can attempt to stop the ritual by attacking, imobilizing or killing the cultists or the prisoners.

If the ritual fails, Volcathar will join the fight for 2 rounds before retreating to his lair weakened by the incomplete ritual.

Depending on the party's power level, the GM can adjust the timing of the sacrifices to 2 or 3 rounds between each prisoner being thrown into the vortex to maintain an appropriate level of challenge.

Volcathar canot engage the party until the ritual either succeeds or is disrupted.

The cultists are fanatically focused on their task of throwing prisoners into the vortex, and only if directly threatened will they stop their actions to defend themselves.

After the ritual is complete or intrerrupted, Korvan will fight but eventually will try to flee to the lair beleaving that the dragon is under his control.

Flavor Dialogue

Father Korvan (in the middle of the ritual): "Witness the flames that will birth a god!"

Father Korvan (in the middle of the ritual): "Volcathar’s ascension is upon us! No one can stop the Flameborn!"

Father Korvan (in the middle of the ritual): "The fire consumes, the dragon awakens!"

Father Korvan (as the dragon retreats): "Fools! You see? Volcathar obeys my will! The Flameborn is mine to command, his power bound to me by the ritual."

Father Korvan (as the dragon retreats): "You thought to disrupt the ascension, but you’ve only delayed the inevitable!"

Cultists: "Your deaths will fuel our master's rise!"

Cultists: "The Flameborn shall devour the skies!"

Cultists: "Another soul to stoke the flames of ascension!"

Volcathar (if the ritual is completed): "Fools... You have witnessed the birth of true power!"

Volcathar (when he retreats): "Pray that I sleep for a long, long time... for when I awaken, your world will be nothing but cinders!"

Volcathar (after a prisoner is thrown in the vortex): “Each sacrifice fuels the inferno, and the flames will soon consume all!”

Map Notes

  1. Entrance

  2. Fire Vortex

  3. Father Korvan

Dragon Lair

If the party skip the Ritual Site and goes straight to the lair

When the party enters the lair, they find it mostly empty, with only one prisoner held captive. As they explore further, they discover murals in the Great Hallway. A successful Religion DC 15 check reveals the dragon’s plan to reach adulthood through a sacrificial ritual. At this point, the dragon will arrive in the lair from the ritual site in its adult form, though still weakened by the ritual. It will retain the same abilities and stats as its younger form. He needs [[/roll 1d6 + 6]] months of sleep to fully complete its transformation.

Initially, the dragon will engage in combat for a few rounds. However, having achieved his goal, he will begin to bargain with the players. He will offer a deal: he will not attack the nearby village and will retreat to sleep for an extended period if they bring him the heads of the cultists and their leader, Korvan, who tried to control him for his own ends. Just as the dragon makes his offer, Korvan and his cultists will arrive at the lair, prompting the dragon to say:

Volcathar: "The betrayers arrive just as I expected. Punish them in my name and I shall reward your deed."

If the party accepts the deal:

  • They will engage in battle against Korvan and his cultists, with the dragon observing. After Korvan is defeated, Volcathar will honor his bargain. He will retreat to his slumber, telling the party to leave immediately and warning them not to test his patience again.

If the party refuses the deal:

  • Volcathar will mockingly turn to Korvan, asking if he seeks mercy and offering him the chance to kill the party. Korvan, still believing he can control the dragon, will submit to the command.

In any situation, if Volcathar's health drops too low, he may retreat into the lava beneath his lair, vowing to return and hunt down the party once his transformation is complete.

Should the players attempt to steal from his hoard, the cavern will violently tremble, causing the lava to rise. They will have only a few minutes to escape before the lair collapses.

If the party disrupted the Ritual Site at Toothmaw Cliffs

At the lair, the party will find Volcathar in a foul mood, devouring the last prisoner while Korvan grovels for mercy. When the dragon sees the party intruding into his domain, his anger flares, and he orders Korvan to deal with the intruders. With his plans shattered and his pride wounded, this is the party’s best chance to defeat the dragon. If they can creatively taunt or lure him into fighting in the open, they stand a chance of slaying the young red dragon.

If the party kills Volcathar and Father Korvan, they can loot the dragon’s hoard.

If the party does not disrupted the Ritual Site at Toothmaw Cliffs

If the party does not disrupt the ritual, Volcathar successfully transforms into an adult dragon. However, weakened by the rapid transformation, he retreats to his lair, leaving the cultists to engage the adventurers. Korvan will also attempt to flee to the lair.

Outcome 1:

If the cult leader manages to escape, the party can follow him there.

Reaching the lair, the party will overhear a brief exchange between Korvan and the dragon:

Korvan: “You’re mine, Volcathar. With this ritual complete, you’ll serve my will. Your power will be ours to command!”

Volcathar: “Foolish mortal, you think you can chain a storm of fire? Your arrogance blinds you. Witness the true cost of defying me.”

Still deluded, Korvan believes he can control Volcathar, but the dragon, amused by the cult leader’s arrogance, mocks him before incinerating him with dragon fire.

If the party chooses to engage the dragon and wounds him too severely, he will submerge into the lava, swearing revenge once he fully recovers.

Volcathar will require [[/roll 1d6 + 6]] months of sleep to fully complete his transformation. Should the party touch his hoard, the dragon’s wrath will trigger a magical collapse of the cavern, and they will only have a few minutes to escape before being buried alive.

Outcome 2:

If Korvan does not manage to escape.

Reaching the lair, the dragon will remain hidden until they discover his hoard. Once they do, Volcathar will either engage them in battle or attempt to bargain. If he chooses to fight, his abilities remain the same as before, though his size has increased due to the ritual. Despite this, he still requires [[/roll 1d6 + 6]] months of sleep to fully complete his transformation.

If the battle turns against him and he is critically wounded, Volcathar will retreat into the lava, swearing to hunt the party until the end of time. Should the players attempt to steal from his hoard, the cavern will violently tremble, causing the lava to rise. They will have only a few minutes to escape before the lair collapses.

ADVENTURE HOOKS.name: ADVENTURE HOOKS
ADVENTURE HOOKS.text: A string of settlements, trade posts, and isolated outposts have been annihilated. MAPS.name: MAPS
MAPS.text:
Town Square

The town square is a bustling scene of daily life, with market stalls full of fresh produce and local merchants hawking their wares. The central fountain gently trickles, providing a calming ambiance as the party goes about their business. There is no warning, no hint of danger until it's too late.

Without warning, a shadow looms over the square. Townsfolk glance up in confusion, their faces turning to horror as the sky above them darkens with the silhouette of massive wings. A roar reverberates through the streets, shaking windows and scattering birds. Panic grips the square as people scream and flee, dropping goods and overturning carts in their desperate scramble to escape.

Volcathar, consumed with rage, swoops down from the clouds. His wings create gusts of wind that scatter loose items across the square. The party, caught off guard, has only moments to react. Before they can even raise their weapons or cast their first spells, Volcathar releases a blast of fire from his maw, engulfing the nearest market stalls and setting the square ablaze.

The smell of burning wood and flesh fills the air. Volcathar lands with a crash in the middle of the square with his eyes fixed on the party.

"Did you think you could hide from me, mortals? Now, you will burn!"

Dragon's Tactics

Surprise Attack from Above: Volcathar spots the party from the air and strikes without warning. His initial attack is a blast of flame to scatter and intimidate them, aiming to create chaos and separate the group.

Targeting Vulnerable Party Members: Volcathar focuses on party members that are out in the open first. He will aim for spellcasters or healers, seeing them as a potential threat to his power.

Flame Breath to Burn Buildings: If two or more adventurers enter a building to take cover, Volcathar will immediately shift his focus to that structure. He will unleash his breath upon the building, setting it ablaze with the intention of trapping or forcing the adventurers out. Everyone inside the building must make a Dexterity saving throw with advantage, taking only half damage on a success. In [[/roll 1d4]] rounds, the building collapses.

Town Guards: If the town guard starts to gather, Volcathar may retreat to avoid an overwhelming counterattack.

If the Party Flees: If most of the party flees, Volcathar laughs cruelly.

“Flee, cowards! You can run all you want, but my flames will find you again!”

He watches them scatter before setting a final building ablaze and soaring away into the sky, leaving the town square in ruins.

Lava Fall

This map can be used if the previous lair was destroyed by the party actions during their first encounter with Volcathar. Now, having tracked the dragon back to his domain, the adventurers find a dark, rocky plateau rising above a surrounding river of molten lava.

Furious at their daring intrusion, Volcathar prepares to make his final stand. This plateau is all that remains of his sanctuary, and seeing the adventurers invade it fills him with rage. Here, encircled by the river of lava, the dragon plans to fight to the death, determined to turn his enemies into ashes.

Tower of the Broken Mind.name: Tower of the Broken Mind
Tower of the Broken Mind.description:
A mysterious tower has appeared on the coast, causing violent storms and disrupting the natural order. Within the tower resides the fractured remnants of its creator, the Architect, whose failed experiment shattered his personality into five aspects: the Scholar (logic), the Dreamer (emotion), the Visionary (ambition), the Coward (fear), and the Curious (wonder). Each aspect has its own agenda, shaped by the Architect’s failed experiment to sever an unwanted part of him.

The adventurers must traverse the tower’s levels, solving puzzles, navigating traps, and overcoming challenges, while deciding which aspects to aid and which to exclude from the experiment. Along the way, they uncover the tower’s secrets, including its unstable void-powered magic, its connection to a petrified blue dragon, and the wizard’s struggles with ambition, love, and regret.

The adventure combines exploration, moral dilemmas, and combat, challenging the adventurers to balance logic, emotion, ambition, fear, and curiosity as they unravel the mystery of the tower.

Mirror Image.description:
Three illusory duplicates of yourself appear in your space. Until the spell ends, the duplicates move with you and mimic your actions, shifting position so it's impossible to track which image is real. You can use your action to dismiss the illusory duplicates.

Each time a creature targets you with an attack during the spell's duration, roll a [[/r 1d20 # Mirror Image Check]] to determine whether the attack instead targets one of your duplicates.

If you have three duplicates, you must roll a 6 or higher to change the attack's target to a duplicate. With two duplicates, you must roll an 8 or higher. With one duplicate, you must roll an 11 or higher.

A duplicate's AC equals 10 + your Dexterity modifier. If an attack hits a duplicate, the duplicate is destroyed. A duplicate can be destroyed only by an attack that hits it. It ignores all other damage and effects. The spell ends when all three duplicates are destroyed.

A creature is unaffected by this spell if it can't see, if it relies on senses other than sight, such as blindsight, or if it can perceive illusions as false, as with truesight.

This staff is not meant for melee attacks but while you hold it, you gain a +2 bonus to ranged spell attack rolls and it has 10 charges. It regains 1d4 + 2 expended charges after a long rest. If you expend the last charge, roll a d20. On a 20, the staff regains 2d4 + 2 charges.

The storm creates dangerous terrain, making the ground slippery and filled with debris, making it difficult for creatures within the area of effect to move around. The winds, lightning strikes and heavy rain make it hard for creatures to see or hear, imposing disadvantage on any perception checks made while within the storm. The storm also unleashes bolts of lightning, forcing creatures within the affected area, to make a Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save they take [[/r 8d6]] lightning damage, or half as much on a successful one.

ADVENTURE SUMMARY.name: ADVENTURE SUMMARY
ADVENTURE SUMMARY.text:
A mysterious tower has appeared on the coast, causing violent storms and disrupting the natural order. Within the tower resides the fractured remnants of its creator, @UUID[Actor.7WjHNfX4PWEE1YIP]{The Architect}, whose failed experiment shattered his personality into five aspects: @UUID[Actor.qkJAdaRGhEk5CSXu]{The Scholar} (logic), @UUID[Actor.fHBGmHDIeDlMG9eP]{The Dreamer} (emotion), @UUID[Actor.ZOHYhK9nl6q4Nfq7]{The Visionary} (ambition), @UUID[Actor.5B7BWcyF2jB8peTd]{The Coward} (fear), and @UUID[Actor.9XjOpzeCG7YC6lz9]{The Curious} (wonder). Each aspect has its own agenda, shaped by the Architect’s failed experiment to sever an unwanted part of him.

The adventurers must traverse the tower’s levels, solving puzzles, navigating traps, and overcoming challenges, while deciding which aspects to aid and which to exclude from the experiment. Along the way, they uncover the tower’s secrets, including its unstable void-powered magic, its connection to a petrified blue dragon, and the wizard’s struggles with ambition, love, and regret.

The adventure combines exploration, moral dilemmas, and combat, challenging the adventurers to balance logic, emotion, ambition, fear, and curiosity as they unravel the mystery of the tower.

The adventure can be summarized in 3 acts:

Act 1: The Puzzle of the Entrance
The adventurers explore the lower levels of the tower, meet the five aspects representing the different personalities of the Architect, and solve the orb puzzle at the entrance. Completing the puzzle stabilizes the tower’s arcane flow and unlocks access to the upper levels.

Act 2: The Roof Confrontation
The adventurers ascend to the roof to retrieve energy cells required to power the experiment and reunite the fractured personalities of the Architect. On the roof, they face environmental hazards and battle voidling elementals drawn to the unstable energy.

Act 3: The Experiment and the Final Confrontation
In the Arcane Circle room, the adventurers power the experiment, solve the light-beam puzzle, and select a maximum of four aspects to reunite in the Architect’s mind. When the Architect is summoned, the excluded aspect exerts control over his mind, while any aspects whose quests were not completed turn hostile. The adventurers must defeat these enemies, stabilize the Architect, and determine the tower’s final fate.

MECHANICS.name: MECHANICS
MECHANICS.text:
Macros for GM

  • @UUID[Macro.kfOzqfjgG8VQErb5]{Enable/Disable Regions}

    • Can be used on all maps. It enables or disables Region Behaviors. For example, you can use it to enable or disable teleporting regions so that players won’t be teleported when entering a specific region. For some regions (like stairs), it makes sense for the teleport behavior to always remain active. However, for others (such as puzzle-related areas), it may be more appropriate to activate the region behavior only after players have solved the puzzles, making the region’s activation logical within the context of the game.
      Since the macro is generic, it will display all regions with behaviors, such as weather suppression for indoor areas.

  • @UUID[Macro.pL9tL6WRxevy4dzt]{Turn On/Off Lights}

    • Can be used on @UUID[JournalEntry.7gwobmg96g7RltZa.JournalEntryPage.oJ2hCQwm9QjTTvaM]{Lower Level 1: Storage} | @UUID[JournalEntry.7gwobmg96g7RltZa.JournalEntryPage.JuU0tRHMY9VMyqXx]{Level 1: Entrance} | @UUID[JournalEntry.7gwobmg96g7RltZa.JournalEntryPage.W5oyMESfEMDQf3qV]{Level 6: Arcane Circle}. Its purpose is to easily turn certain scene lights on or off.

  • @UUID[Macro.aoJCylLS71Pvq3Ln]{Rotate Lights}

    • Can be used on @UUID[JournalEntry.7gwobmg96g7RltZa.JournalEntryPage.W5oyMESfEMDQf3qV]{Level 6: Arcane Circle}. Its purpose is to easily rotate certain lights in the scene and power on the experiment (turn on all lights).

  • @UUID[Macro.T5uKOQfZV5fPKLUh]{Summon Tokens}

    • Can be used on @UUID[JournalEntry.7gwobmg96g7RltZa.JournalEntryPage.W5oyMESfEMDQf3qV]{Level 6: Arcane Circle}. Its purpose is to summon tokens onto the canvas in predefined locations.
      This macro does check if an actor is already on the map, and it will prevent summoning a duplicate of the same actor. However, the macro does not keep track of which spawn positions have already been used if you run it multiple times in separate actions. So if you summon one actor (which lands at the first position) and then re-run the macro later for a different actor, that second actor will also appear at that same first position.

  • @UUID[Macro.XGylSKw442aj9aXJ]{Trigger Trap}

    • Can be used on all maps but it is recommended for @UUID[JournalEntry.7gwobmg96g7RltZa.JournalEntryPage.LHTYFArNIsP4yFRB]{Level 3: Study}. Its purpose is to deal damage to the token that attempted to open the chest using an incorrect code.

GM Notes:

  • Some regions with teleportation behavior are intentionally disabled to prevent players from teleporting before solving certain puzzles.
    You can enable or disable the teleport regions using the provided macro or directly from Foundry Region Control.

  • It is normal for the custom macros to close when the GM changes the map. This behavior is intentional, as the information presented in the dialog becomes irrelevant once the map changes.

  • If the players attack and kill an aspect, it will disappear from the map, and the players will no longer be able to communicate with it by any means. Additionally, the aspect will not be able to participate in the experiment.

  • Be sure to check the Handout Journals for additional information—especially the Wizard’s Journal Notes, which can be found in various parts of the tower.

ADVENTURE HOOKS.name: ADVENTURE HOOKS
ADVENTURE HOOKS.text:
1. The Coastal Calamity

Violent storms have ravaged the coast, cutting off trade routes and flooding villages. Locals report that the storms began when a strange tower appeared near the shoreline. The adventurers are hired by desperate villagers to investigate the source of the storms and put an end to them.

2. A Village in Peril

An isolated fishing village near the tower is under constant assault from elementals. The villagers plead with the adventurers to stop the attacks and stabilize the region.

3. The Disrupted Arcane Council

A council of wizards sends a formal request for adventurers to investigate the tower. They warn that the tower’s unstable magic is interfering with their own experiments and could unravel important protective wards in the region.

TOWER LEVEL 1.name: TOWER LEVEL 1
TOWER LEVEL 1.text:
Entrance

Description

The Entrance Room contains a central crystalline magical device connected by multiple energy lines to eight glowing orbs. The device is unstable and linked to the tower's arcane systems. On the opposite side of the room, a stone throne is positioned between two larger orbs. A staircase leads upward, and another staircase descends to a lower level.

Puzzle

The puzzle in the entrance room involves eight energy orbs that can be turned on or off. To solve it, the adventurers must determine which orbs need to be activated and the correct sequence to activate them. The first clue is found in the @UUID[JournalEntry.Y3ga0FQtUAMPQNaU]{Handout: Codex of the Arcane Engine}, located in the Bedroom. If the adventurers bring the codex to the @UUID[Actor.qkJAdaRGhEk5CSXu]{Scholar}, he explains that each orb at the entrance is linked to specific rooms in the tower. The adventurers must identify which orbs are pulsing in each room and activate the corresponding orbs at the entrance in ascending order based on the tower's levels.

Hint: Pulsing orbs can be seen more clearly in the dark.

Solution: In the Entrance Room, there are two large orbs, but only one is pulsing. This orb must be pressed first. The next set of orbs is in the Specimen Room, where three of the five orbs are pulsing at varying speeds. These three orbs can be pressed in any order after the first. The final pulsing orb is located in the Bedroom and is the only orb in that room. At the entrance, the corresponding orb must be activated last to complete the sequence.

Outcome: The levitation glyph in the Bedroom is now active and provides access to the Arcane Circle room.

Hazards

The small orbs are interactive and can be switched on or off. Activating the orbs in the incorrect order cause the crystalline device to release harmful energy or summon elementals:

  • On the first incorrect activation, the crystalline magical device summons three elementals to attack the adventurers.

  • For each subsequent incorrect activation, the following effects occur in sequence:

    1. Sonic damage, use the Sonic Damage from the orb's abilities.

    2. Lightning damage, use the Lightning Damage from the orb's abilities.

    3. Necrotic damage.

After these three effects, if the adventurers continue pressing the orbs in the wrong sequence, the GM can choose which ability of the crystalline magical device to activate next.
Additionally, when the crystalline device triggers any of its harmful abilities due to an incorrect sequence, all the orbs turn off, forcing the adventurers to start the sequence again.

Note: The crystalline magical device cannot be destroyed. While players may attempt to attack it, it is immune to all types of damage.

Because of the tower's volatile arcane energy and chaotic weather, aerial movement is far too dangerous to attempt.
Climbing the tower requires DC 18 Strength (Athletics) check every round for climbing the polished surface. Failure results in a slip, losing 15ft of progress, and requiring a DC 16 Dexterity saving throw to avoid falling. A creature affected by the Spider Climb spell bypasses the need for climbing checks entirely.
Falling damage is 1d6 bludgeoning for every 10ft fallen. Each floor has a height of 14ft.
If they manage to climb to level 5, they will find a balcony with locked doors. A DC 16 Dexterity (Thieves' Tools) check is required to pick the lock, or a DC 20 Strength (Athletics) check to brute-force the door. Similarly, if they climb to level 6, they will encounter another set of locked doors with the same requirements. If they climb to level 7 and reach the roof, they will trigger a combat encounter.

Interactive Map Features

@UUID[Macro.kfOzqfjgG8VQErb5]{Enable/Disable Regions} (enables or disables teleporting regions)

@UUID[Macro.pL9tL6WRxevy4dzt]{Lights Orb Puzzle} (easily turn on/off the puzzle lights)

TOWER LEVEL 2.name: TOWER LEVEL 2
TOWER LEVEL 2.text:
The Library

Description

The Library is located on Level 2 of the tower. It is a large, octagonal room with walls lined by bookshelves, each filled with numerous tomes, scrolls, and manuscripts. A central wooden walkway, illuminated by dim lanterns on either end, spans the room, connecting opposite sides of the chamber. Two staircases are present: one leading upward to the next floor and another descending to the lower level.

@UUID[Actor.qkJAdaRGhEk5CSXu]{The Scholar}

The Scholar, one of the wizard’s fractured aspects, appears in this room as an ethereal, translucent figure resembling a man. He is surrounded by open books and focused on deciphering an old text. When he notices the adventurers, he says:

"Ah, outsiders. Finally, someone with the intellect to end this mess."

Personality: Logical, analytical, and reserved. Prefers knowledge over action and is cautious about revealing too much information.

Some examples of responses he might give to adventurers' questions:

If asked who he is:
"I am a fragment, a mind shaped by logic."

If asked about this place:
"This is the library. It has seen better days, but its purpose remains intact if you know where to look."

If asked about what happened:
"An experiment gone wrong. The consequences, as you can see, have been catastrophic."

If asked about anything else in the tower:
"I'm afraid my memory is quite... fragmented. Likely a result of the experiment. I remember flashes, pieces, but the whole picture eludes me. Perhaps some answers lie within the tower itself..."

If asked about the orbs on the first floor before the book is retrieved he respond with the request.
"A sealed book bound in chains lies somewhere within the tower. Find it for me, and I will share everything I know."

Why can’t you find the book yourself?
"I am bound to this floor, a consequence of the experiment’s failure. My presence cannot extend beyond these walls."

If asked about the orbs on the first floor after retrieving the book, the Scholar continues to read for a little while before responding:
"Ah, the orbs at the entrance... each one is linked to specific rooms within the tower. Their pulsing indicates a connection to the tower’s arcane flow, a pattern, if you will. To stabilize the magic, you must observe which orbs are active in each room and replicate their order at the entrance. Begin with the lowest level and work your way upward, pressing the corresponding orbs in sequence."

If the adventurers ask about how to better observe the orbs, the Scholar can respond:
"The pulsing orbs are probably more noticeable in the dark."

TOWER LEVEL 3.name: TOWER LEVEL 3
TOWER LEVEL 3.text:
The Study Room

Description

The Study Room contains a central wooden table surrounded by chairs. Shelves along the walls hold various tools, alchemical instruments, and jars labeled with unknown contents. A desk near the edge of the room displays additional notes, charts, and partially completed projects.

Two staircases provide access to other levels, one leading upward and one downward.

@UUID[Actor.ZOHYhK9nl6q4Nfq7]{The Visionary}

The Visionary, one of the wizard’s fractured aspects, is present in the room positioned near the desk, examining a schematic.

When the Visionary notices the adventurers, he turns toward them and says:

"Finally, someone with potential."

Personality: Ambitious, determined, and focused on progress. Values the future above all, often disregarding the past.

Some examples of responses he might give to adventurers' questions:

If asked who he is:
"I am the Visionary, the drive to achieve, to create, and to push beyond limits. A fragment of the mind that sought to overcome its flaws. Now I remain as a shadow of that ambition."

If asked about the tower:
"This tower was built as a vessel for a grand experiment. It was to separate and refine aspects of the self, to achieve perfection. What you see now are the remnants of that ambition."

If asked about the orbs from the first floor:
"The orbs? A minor piece of the larger puzzle. They may have their purpose, but our focus must remain on the experiment and what went wrong."

If asked about what happened:
"The experiment was meant to isolate one undesirable trait from the whole, an act of self-purification. But the energy became unstable. The process fractured everything, scattering the aspects and destabilizing the tower."

If asked how many aspects there are:
"There are five of us, fragments of what was once a whole. Some of them are less predictable, but they exist within this tower."

If asked about the Scholar:
"The Scholar? A fragment of reason, confined to his books and theories. He has his uses, knowledge is but a tool after all, but he lacks the drive to act."

If asked about anything else in the tower:
"Look, we must focus on what must be done. The details of the past are insignificant compared to the vision of what can be achieved. Seek the future, not the past."

Request:
"You must help me reunite the aspects. But first, go to the Arcane Circle room where the experiment took place. There lies an arcane device. With it, I can better understand what went wrong and what must be done to make things right."

If the adventurers bring the @UUID[JournalEntry.9ej6q4lJuSRlmX6v]{Arcane Device} to the Visionary, after a short inspection, he can say the following:
"Is what I suspected, the energy cells... Their calibration was always a challenge, given the unstable nature of the void energy. That instability, I believe, was the cause of the experiment’s failure. But now, I know how to align them properly. There should still be functional @UUID[JournalEntry.JfhUJ3tVp25bSmxV]{Energy Cells} on the roof. Retrieve them, and we can ensure the device works as intended this time."

After the adventurers bring the energy cells to the Visionary, he can say the following:
"Good, give me a moment. Now, you must absorb into the device the aspects you wish to participate in the experiment. There must be at least one, but no more than four. I demand that one of them be me if not the only one. My role is essential to the whole. Without me, none of this would be possible. Once the aspects are absorbed, take the device to the Arcane Circle room and place it on the stone table to power the experiment. If everything functions as intended, the wall crystals will emit magical light beams, and the absorbed aspects will be channeled into the enclosures, with violet arcane shields activating around them. To complete the sequence, redirect the light beams so that each connects to a crystal node on the arcane circle. The flow of light must move in a continuous anticlockwise direction to properly power the experiment."

Hazards

Falling damage is 1d6 bludgeoning for every 10ft fallen. Each floor has a height of 14ft.

TOWER LEVEL 4.name: TOWER LEVEL 4
TOWER LEVEL 4.text:
The Specimen Room

Description

This level contains a series of display cases showcasing preserved specimens and artifacts. The room features a central case displaying a massive nautilus creature. Other cases hold insects pinned in frames, and other strange objects. Warm, golden light from glowing orbs highlights the displays.

Two staircases provide access to the levels above and below.

@UUID[Actor.9XjOpzeCG7YC6lz9]{The Curious}

The Curious, another aspect of the fractured wizard, resides here, studying the exhibits.

When the Curious notices the adventurers, he says:

"Oh, visitors! How wonderful! Have you seen the specimens? Aren’t they fascinating? I knew someone would come eventually."

Peronality: Enthusiastic and impulsive, they often dive into mysteries without caution, valuing discovery over safety.

Some examples of responses he might give to adventurers' questions:

If asked who he is:
"I am a seeker, a collector of wonders. I observe, I question, and perhaps, in time, I understand."

If asked about this place:
"A collection, a treasury of life’s diversity and peculiarities. Each piece tells a story, don’t you think?"

If asked about the orbs from the first floor:
"Orbs, you say? Devices of focus and control, perhaps. They are part of the tower's mechanisms, but their function escapes me. Maybe others can illuminate the matter."

If asked about what happened:
"An experiment unraveled, spilling chaos into order. I cannot say more without speculation, but the results... they are all around us."

If asked about the other aspects:
"Ah, an intriguing thought. I sense five of us, each holding something the others lack. It’s strange how we’re separate yet connected, isn’t it?"

If asked about anything else in the tower:
"Oh, the tower holds so many secrets, and I don't have all the answers..."

If asked about the odor:
"Odor? Hmm... curious indeed. I cannot perceive it myself, as I lack a physical body. But perhaps it is connected to the decay of these specimens? An unfortunate side effect of their... preservation methods and the residual magic saturating this place."

If the adventurers are poisoned, the Curious says:
Ah, I see the room's... lingering effect has taken hold. Unfortunate, but not entirely irreversible. Tell me outsiders, do you intend to reunite the aspects?"

If the adventurers express willingness, the Curious nods and continues:
"Good. Then I must insist on one condition: when the time comes, you will include me in the merging. Promise me this, and I will guide you where to find an antidote."

If the adventurers agree to the terms, he reveals:
"Very well. Beneath this tower, there lies a room... where darker purposes once guided experiments. There you may find an antidote. Proceed with caution. It is a place best left undisturbed."

Hazards

The Specimen Room has a faint but pervasive strange odor caused by decayed remains and magical contamination. For every minute adventurers spend in the room, they must succeed on a DC 18 Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, they become poisoned and gain 3 levels of Exhaustion. This Exhaustion cannot be removed by resting or sleeping. It requires magical healing, such as the use of a lesser restoration spell or similar effects that cure poison and exhaustion. On a successful save, they become immune to the effect.

Falling damage is 1d6 bludgeoning for every 10ft fallen. Each floor has a height of 14ft.

TOWER LEVEL 5.name: TOWER LEVEL 5
TOWER LEVEL 5.text:
The Bedroom

Description

In the center of this room is an arcane glyph engraved into the stone floor. The glyph emits a faint glow, indicating its magical properties. Above the glyph, the ceiling contains a sealed circular aperture. Activating the glyph opens the aperture and levitates individuals to the next floor. A bed is positioned against the western wall, accompanied by a small nightstands.

@UUID[Actor.fHBGmHDIeDlMG9eP]{The Dreamer}

Near the northern wall are three large mirrors. The Dreamer stands before them, studying the reflections.

When the Dreamer notices the adventurers, he says:

“Oh… you’ve come to fix us, haven’t you? I can sense your intentions.”
He gestures to the mirrors and adds, “Even in these reflections, I appear as though I am part of a dream.”

Personality: Gentle and empathetic. Seeks harmony but is often lost in thoughts of "what could be."

If asked about the mirrors:
“These mirrors… they reflect more than the present. They capture glimpses of what was, and sometimes, what could be. It’s not just my reflection I see. It’s… potential, perhaps? Or regret.”

If asked about the experiment:
“Ah, the folly of ambition. So much was risked in the name of progress, and yet here we are… fragments of what was once whole.”

If asked about anything else in the tower:
"The tower... it is a labyrinth of forgotten dreams. I feel its whispers, but their meaning escapes me."

If asked about the other aspects:
“Each of us carries a part of the wizard’s essence, yet we are so different. One dreams too big, unheeding of the cost. Another cold, calculating would sacrifice much for knowledge. I… I only wish for peace, but perhaps that’s my flaw.”

If asked about the chained book:

"If it is truly needed, I will not stop you."

If asked about the glyph:
“The glyph will lift those who stand on it to the next floor where the experiment was conducted.”

Request:
"There is something I yearn to see again. In the storage room, there lies a chest. Forgotten, neglected, yet holding something precious to me: a small locket. Will you bring it back to me?”

Hazards

Falling damage is 1d6 bludgeoning for every 10ft fallen. Each floor has a height of 14ft.

TOWER LEVEL 6.name: TOWER LEVEL 6
TOWER LEVEL 6.text:
Arcane Circle

Description

The Arcane Circle is an octagonal room with eight crystals embedded in the walls. Three walls display paintings of the wizard in various scenes, possibly connected to the tower's history. Four walls feature enclosures, and at the northern end of the room, a stone table holds an @UUID[JournalEntry.9ej6q4lJuSRlmX6v]{Arcane Device}. In the center, an aperture leads to the room below, surrounded by energy lines forming an arcane circle with crystals positioned around the nodes. Two closed doors lead to an exterior ledge encircling the room. Metal ladders located at the north and south sides of the ledge provide access to the roof.

Puzzle (The Experiment)

If the adventurers investigate the @UUID[JournalEntry.9ej6q4lJuSRlmX6v]{Arcane Device}, they will notice its @UUID[JournalEntry.JfhUJ3tVp25bSmxV]{Energy Cells} are depleted. By bringing the device to the Visionary, they will learn it requires functional energy cells, which can be obtained from devices on the roof. After retrieving the energy cells, the adventurers must return to the Visionary to install them. This time, they will learn that they must absorb at least one aspect, but no more than four, into the arcane device. Once this is done, the adventurers must return the device to the Arcane Circle room to power the experiment. Once powered, the crystals on the walls will emit magical light beams, and the absorbed aspects will be channeled into the enclosures, with violet arcane shields activating around them. The adventurers must then solve the light beam puzzle to progress.

Note: While inside the enclosures, the aspects are dormant and incapable of any form of communication or interaction. If the adventurers choose to explore the tower again after the combat encounter, the GM should remove the tokens of any aspects left behind in the rooms.

Solution: To complete the puzzle, they must redirect the beams of light emitted by the wall crystals so that every beam illuminates a crystal node on the arcane circle. The light beams must flow in a continuous anticlockwise pattern to properly power the experiment.

Outcome: The aperture in the middle of the room will lock for 1 minute and @UUID[Actor.7WjHNfX4PWEE1YIP]{The Architect} materializes in the center, mentally unstable and dominated by the influence of the aspect excluded from the experiment. Any aspects in the enclosures whose requests were not fulfilled by the adventurers will emerge hostile. The adventurers must defeat the hostile aspects and deplete the Architect’s temporary hit points. Once stabilized, the Architect will regain calm and be able to speak normally, and the hostile aspects will disappear.

Hazards
